text: talk about supervised learning. But, in particular what

text: of supervised learning, and one particular way to

text: about are classification. And regression. And we're going to

text: what we're talking about, something like, true or false.

text: So, what's a good example of that? Imagine

video_name: ID3 - Georgia Tech - Machine Learning
text: the ID3 algorithm. You're simply going to keep looping forever until you've

video_name: ID3 - Georgia Tech - Machine Learning
text: solved the problem. At each step, you're going to pick the best attribute,

text: we talked about, assign that as a decision attribute for node.

text: And then for each value that the attribute A can take on,

video_name: ID3 - Georgia Tech - Machine Learning
text: create a descendent of node. Sort the training examples

video_name: ID3 - Georgia Tech - Machine Learning
text: to those leaves based upon exactly what values they

video_name: ID3 - Georgia Tech - Machine Learning
text: take on, and if you've perfectly classified your training

video_name: ID3 - Georgia Tech - Machine Learning
text: set, then you stop. Otherwise, you iterate over each

video_name: ID3 - Georgia Tech - Machine Learning
text: of those leaves, picking the best attribute in turn

video_name: ID3 - Georgia Tech - Machine Learning
text: for the training examples that were sorted into that

video_name: ID3 - Georgia Tech - Machine Learning
text: leaf, and you keep doing that. Building up the

video_name: ID3 - Georgia Tech - Machine Learning
text: tree until you're done. So that's the ID3 algorithm.

text: >> So, we've got a whole bunch of trees we have

text: to look at, Michael. And were going to have to come up with

video_name: ID3 Bias - Georgia Tech - Machine Learning
text: bias. And in particular, the notion of inductive bias. Now, just

video_name: ID3 Bias - Georgia Tech - Machine Learning
text: as a quick refresher, I'm want to remind you that there is

video_name: ID3 Bias - Georgia Tech - Machine Learning
text: two kind of biases we worrying about when we think about algorithms

video_name: ID3 Bias - Georgia Tech - Machine Learning
text: that are searching through space. One is what's called a restriction bias.

video_name: ID3 Bias - Georgia Tech - Machine Learning
text: The other is called preference bias.

video_name: ID3 Bias - Georgia Tech - Machine Learning
text: So a restriction bias is nothing more than

video_name: ID3 Bias - Georgia Tech - Machine Learning
text: the hypothesis set that you actually care about. So

video_name: ID3 Bias - Georgia Tech - Machine Learning
text: in this case, with the decision trees, the

video_name: ID3 Bias - Georgia Tech - Machine Learning
text: hypothesis set is all possible decision trees. Okay? That

video_name: ID3 Bias - Georgia Tech - Machine Learning
text: means we're not considering, y equals 2x plus

video_name: ID3 Bias - Georgia Tech - Machine Learning
text: 3. We're not considering quadratic equations. We're not considering

video_name: ID3 Bias - Georgia Tech - Machine Learning
text: non-boolean functions of a certain type. We're only considering

video_name: ID3 Bias - Georgia Tech - Machine Learning
text: decision trees, and all that they can represent. And

video_name: ID3 Bias - Georgia Tech - Machine Learning
text: nothing else. Okay? So that's already a restriction bias

video_name: ID3 Bias - Georgia Tech - Machine Learning
text: and it's important. Because, instead of looking at the infinite

video_name: ID3 Bias - Georgia Tech - Machine Learning
text: number uncountably infinite number of functions that are out there,

video_name: ID3 Bias - Georgia Tech - Machine Learning
text: that we might consider. We're only going to consider those

video_name: ID3 Bias - Georgia Tech - Machine Learning
text: that can be represented by a decision tree over

video_name: ID3 Bias - Georgia Tech - Machine Learning
text: in, you know, all the cases we've given so far

video_name: ID3 Bias - Georgia Tech - Machine Learning
text: discreet variable. But a preference bias is something that's just

video_name: ID3 Bias - Georgia Tech - Machine Learning
text: as important. And it tells us what source of hypotheses

video_name: ID3 Bias - Georgia Tech - Machine Learning
text: from this hypothesis set we prefer,

video_name: ID3 Bias - Georgia Tech - Machine Learning
text: and that is really at the heart of inductive bias. So Michael,

text: basically good splits near the top than a tree that has bad splits

video_name: ID3 Bias - Georgia Tech - Machine Learning
text: at the top. Even if the two trees can represent the same function.

video_name: ID3 Bias - Georgia Tech - Machine Learning
text: >> Good point.

video_name: ID3 Bias - Georgia Tech - Machine Learning
text: So good splits near the top.

video_name: ID3 Bias - Georgia Tech - Machine Learning
text: better to ones that model the data worse.

video_name: ID3 Bias - Georgia Tech - Machine Learning
text: >> Right. So this is one that people often forget: it prefers

video_name: ID3 Bias - Georgia Tech - Machine Learning
text: correct ones to incorrect ones. So, given a tree that has very

video_name: ID3 Bias - Georgia Tech - Machine Learning
text: good splits at the top but produces the wrong answer. It will

video_name: ID3 Bias - Georgia Tech - Machine Learning
text: not take that one over one that doesn't have as good splits at

video_name: ID3 Bias - Georgia Tech - Machine Learning
text: the top, but does give you the correct answer. So that's really,

video_name: ID3 Bias - Georgia Tech - Machine Learning
text: those are really the two main things that are the inductive bias

video_name: ID3 Bias - Georgia Tech - Machine Learning
text: good splits at the top. Because you're going to take trees

video_name: ID3 Bias - Georgia Tech - Machine Learning
text: that actually separate the data well by labels, you're going to

video_name: ID3 Bias - Georgia Tech - Machine Learning
text: tend to come to the answer faster than you would if

text: you didn't do that. So, if you go back to

text: the example where we went before, where one of the attributes

text: doesn't split the data at all, that is not something that ID3 would

video_name: ID3 Bias - Georgia Tech - Machine Learning
text: go for, and it would in fact create a longer and unnecessarily longer tree.

video_name: ID3 Bias - Georgia Tech - Machine Learning
text: So it tends to prefer shorter trees over longer trees. So long as

video_name: ID3 Bias - Georgia Tech - Machine Learning

text: So let me do that and then we can start wondering a little bit

video_name: Ensemble Learning Simple Rules - Georgia Tech - Machine Learning
text: how we're going to make that real. So here's the basic form of an ensemble

video_name: Ensemble Learning Simple Rules - Georgia Tech - Machine Learning
text: learning algorithm. Basically you learn over a

video_name: Ensemble Learning Simple Rules - Georgia Tech - Machine Learning
text: subset of the data, and that generates

video_name: Ensemble Learning Simple Rules - Georgia Tech - Machine Learning
text: some kind of a rule. And then you learn over another subset of the data

video_name: Ensemble Learning Simple Rules - Georgia Tech - Machine Learning
text: and that generates a different rule. And then you learn over another subset of

video_name: Ensemble Learning Simple Rules - Georgia Tech - Machine Learning
text: the data and that generates yet a third rule, and yet a fourth rule, and

video_name: Ensemble Learning Simple Rules - Georgia Tech - Machine Learning
text: yet a fifth rule, and so on and so forth. And then eventually you

video_name: Ensemble Learning Simple Rules - Georgia Tech - Machine Learning
text: take all of those rules and you combine them into one of these complex rules.

video_name: Ensemble Learning Simple Rules - Georgia Tech - Machine Learning
text: So, we might imagine in the email case that I might

video_name: Ensemble Learning Simple Rules - Georgia Tech - Machine Learning
text: look at a small subset of email that I know is already

text: at the other subset of mail. And do the same thing and

video_name: Ensemble Learning Simple Rules - Georgia Tech - Machine Learning

video_name: Ensemble Learning Simple Rules - Georgia Tech - Machine Learning

video_name: Ensemble Learning Simple Rules - Georgia Tech - Machine Learning

text: works. It makes some sense to me, but I think that

video_name: Good Answers - Georgia Tech - Machine Learning
text: in the end what has to happen is you. You, there

video_name: Good Answers - Georgia Tech - Machine Learning
text: must be just a few examples in a kind of weighted sense

video_name: Good Answers - Georgia Tech - Machine Learning
text: that you're getting wrong. And so if I'm right, that as

video_name: Good Answers - Georgia Tech - Machine Learning
text: you, as you move through each of these cycles, you're weighting

video_name: Good Answers - Georgia Tech - Machine Learning
text: in such a way that you have to be picking up

video_name: Good Answers - Georgia Tech - Machine Learning
text: things you've gotten wrong in the past. So in other words,

video_name: Good Answers - Georgia Tech - Machine Learning
text: it's not enough to say, only the things that are

video_name: Good Answers - Georgia Tech - Machine Learning
text: hard in the last set, are the ones that I

video_name: Good Answers - Georgia Tech - Machine Learning
text: have to do better. You must also be picking up

video_name: Good Answers - Georgia Tech - Machine Learning
text: some of the things that you've gotten wrong earlier more

video_name: Good Answers - Georgia Tech - Machine Learning
text: than you were getting right. Because there's just not enough

video_name: Good Answers - Georgia Tech - Machine Learning
text: information in the one's that you're getting right all the

video_name: Good Answers - Georgia Tech - Machine Learning
text: time, because by the time you get that far along,

video_name: Good Answers - Georgia Tech - Machine Learning
text: the weight on them is near zero and they don't matter.

text: >> Interesting.

video_name: Good Answers - Georgia Tech - Machine Learning

video_name: Good Answers - Georgia Tech - Machine Learning
text: yes, but then if you're getting those wrong, they're going to

video_name: Good Answers - Georgia Tech - Machine Learning
text: pull up and you're going to have to start getting

video_name: Good Answers - Georgia Tech - Machine Learning
text: those right too. And so, over time, you've gotta not

video_name: Good Answers - Georgia Tech - Machine Learning

video_name: Good Answers - Georgia Tech - Machine Learning
text: the data. Because there's no way for all of the
